--- title: Coracobrachialis Muscle --- :::{layout-ncol="2"} ![Schematic of Pectoralis major and coracobrachialis @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020
1: Pectoralis Major (clavicular part)
2: Pec Major (Sternocostal part)
3: Pec Major (abdominal part)
4: Coracobrachialis](/The Archive/Anatomy/Skeletal Muscles/Upper Limb Muscles/Axioappendicular Anterior Muscles/images/gilroyatlas fig25.25a pectoralis major and coracobrachialis schematic.png) ![Pectoralis Major and Coracobrachialis, anterior view @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Skeletal Muscles/Upper Limb Muscles/Axioappendicular Anterior Muscles/images/gilroyatlas fig25.25c pectoralis major and coracobrachialis.png) ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Coracobrachialis Coracoid process Humerus (in line with crest of lesser tubercle) Musculocutaneous n.
C5 - C7		 GHJ: Flexion, Adduction, IR
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Coracoid process of [Scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} The *coracobrachialis* inserts on the medial surface of the middle 1/3 of [Humerus]({{< var ref-humerus-bone.path >}}) (in line with crest of lesser tubercle) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} The [musculocutaneous n.]({{< var ref-musculocutaneous-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 and ([C5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c5 >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020, [C6]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c6 >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020, [C7]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c7 >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020) give innervation to the coracobrachialis muscle. - [C5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c5 >}}) has mild-mod distribution @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - [C6]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c6 >}}) and [C7]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c7 >}}) have major distribution @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. [Musculocutaneous n.]({{< var ref-musculocutaneous-nerve.path >}}) innervates the muscle as it passes *through* the muscle @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. # Action {#action} Since the coracobrachialis [originates](#origin) from the scapula and [inserts](#insertion) on the humerus, it primarily affects the [glenohumeral joint (GHJ)]({{< ref-glenohumeral-joint.path >}}). The coracobrachialis performs - GHJ Flexion @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - GHJ Adduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - GHJ Internal rotation @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 When looking at the shoulder as a whole, the coracobrachialis assists with the first 0-60° of shouulder flexion/elevation since this primarily involves the glenohumeral joint @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. # Function Coracobrachialis serves as a [secondary flexor]({{< var ref-shoulder-flexor-muscles.path >}}) and [adductor]({{< var ref-shoulder-adductor-muscles.path >}}) of the shoulder @bielTrailGuideBody2019. The coracobrachialis is usually recruitted when: - Scratching your opposite ear @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Bench press @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Using your forearm to block in front of your chest during combat sports @bielTrailGuideBody2019. # Dysfunction - Since the [musculocutaneous n.]({{< var ref-musculocutaneous-nerve.path >}}) passes through the muscle belly, coracobrachialis dysfunction can entrap the nerve and create neurological symptoms @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. # Pathologies # Palpation The coracobrachialis can be found *deep* to the [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) and [Anterior Deltoid]({{< var ref-deltoid-muscle-anterior.path >}}). The coracobrachialis is *anterior* to [Axillary artery]({{< var ref-axillary-artery.path >}}) and [brachial plexus]({{< var ref-brachial-plexus.path >}}), so be mindful when palpating and applying pressure @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Patient position - Supine @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - 45° GHJ abduction @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - GHJ full external rotation @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: ::: {.column} ### Clinician - Locate [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) (anterior wall of the axilla) @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Place one hand on the medial arm, just proximal to the elbow @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Place the fingerpads of the other hand into the axilla @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Instruct the patient to gently adduct into the non-palpating hand @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Palpate the inferior medial edge of the [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}), this will act as a reference point @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Dive *posterior* to [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.palpation >}}) into the axilla @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Palpate for the "slender" belly of *coracobrachialis* @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Active GHJ adduction should cause it to contract @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: ::: ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Checklist - Is the muscle in the medial arm @bielTrailGuideBody2019? - Is it posterior to [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) @bielTrailGuideBody2019? - Can you strum along the posterior belly @bielTrailGuideBody2019? ::: ::: {.column} ::: ::: # Manual Muscle Test (MMT) {#mmt} According to Dale Avers @aversDanielsWorthinghamsMuscle2019, the coracobrachialis cannot be isolated in a manual muscle test @aversDanielsWorthinghamsMuscle2019. It can, however, be tested alongside other muscles in the shoulder flexion MMT @aversDanielsWorthinghamsMuscle2019. ## Weakness Coracobrachialis weakness can be caused by [musculocutaneous n.]({{< var ref-musculocutaneous-nerve.path >}}) dysfunction @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. # Manual Therapy
